introduction: In this video, we will discuss containerization, a technology that allows developers to create and deploy applications in lightning-fast isolated environments. Containers are essentially full operating systems that can run on top of virtual machines. They are lightning-fast, isolated environments that can be created in mere moments. Containers are a powerful concept that allows developers to create and run applications without having to compromise anything on their local machine. We will explore how to create our own container and the basics of containerization.

sections.title: Section 1: What are Containers?
content: Containers are lightweight and fast environments that can be created in mere moments.
Containers are isolated environments that run on top of virtual machines.
Containers are based on a minimal file system and a kernel.
Containers are used for developing and deploying applications without compromising the local machine.

sections.title: Section 2: Creating a Container Image
content: Containers run from a base file system and some metadata.
Containers are formed with overlapping layers.
Containers can be created with a Dockerfile.
Containers can be created in mere moments.

sections.title: Section 3: Understanding Dockerfile
content: Dockerfile is a script that describes how to build a Docker image.
Dockerfile is executed in sequence and adds each generated change to the final image as a new file system layer.
Dockerfile is used to create a base image.

sections.title: Section 4: Communication between Containers
content: Containers can be put together to form a container orchestration platform.
Containers communicate through a network layer.
Containers are virtualized network layer for you.
Containers can be deployed as standalone units.

sections.title: Section 5: Deploying Containers
content: Containers have built-in support for deploying containers as standalone units.
Containers can be deployed to a cloud platform.
Containers can be deployed to a machine.
Containers can be deployed to a registry.
